item.title: Comment on Book Review: The Basics of Go Strategy by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: Hey! To be honest, I think the order that people read books is highly dependent on their playing style / what they are motivated to improve at the moment. As someone who likes to push the limits of my territory or frameworks, attacking and defense was the more interesting topic to me. On the other hand though, this book does provide a great overview of basic strategy which can be useful across more of the decisions you make during a game. Does that help?
item.content:encoded:
Hey! To be honest, I think the order that people read books is highly dependent on their playing style / what they are motivated to improve at the moment. As someone who likes to push the limits of my territory or frameworks, attacking and defense was the more interesting topic to me.
On the other hand though, this book does provide a great overview of basic strategy which can be useful across more of the decisions you make during a game.
Does that help?

item.title: Comment on Book Review: The Basics of Go Strategy by pollylop
item.dc:creator: pollylop
item.description: Hi Ben, appreciated your review of this book, was wondering would you recommend reading this before Attack and Defense? (will probably read Fundamental Principles of Go before either). Hope things are going well off in development world and that there are chances to enjoy go now and then there.
item.content:encoded: Hi Ben, appreciated your review of this book, was wondering would you recommend reading this before Attack and Defense? (will probably read Fundamental Principles of Go before either). Hope things are going well off in development world and that there are chances to enjoy go now and then there.

item.title: Comment on One-Space Low Pincer-Phobia by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: I hear you man. Sometimes I get so caught up in trying to find the best move or trying to get 100% efficiency that it just gets overwhelming. Glad that the post was helpful. Hope all is well man!
item.content:encoded: I hear you man. Sometimes I get so caught up in trying to find the best move or trying to get 100% efficiency that it just gets overwhelming. Glad that the post was helpful. Hope all is well man!

item.title: Comment on One-Space Low Pincer-Phobia by Aaron Murg
item.dc:creator: Aaron Murg
item.description: I'm right there with you, but with more moves than just the 3-4 pincer! I have an instructor that says to simply find the best move that benefits you. That in and of itself makes sense. It also relieves the pressure I sometimes feel to just start busying myself with memorization. But at the same time, how do you know what's the best move in the beginning. Understanding is better than memorization sure. But understanding is not as easy to come by as memorization in my experience. Thanks Ben!
item.content:encoded: I’m right there with you, but with more moves than just the 3-4 pincer! I have an instructor that says to simply find the best move that benefits you. That in and of itself makes sense. It also relieves the pressure I sometimes feel to just start busying myself with memorization. But at the same time, how do you know what’s the best move in the beginning. Understanding is better than memorization sure. But understanding is not as easy to come by as memorization in my experience. Thanks Ben!

item.title: Comment on Off In Development World… by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: Thanks Molokai. I certainly miss writing here and getting to see everyone's input on things. There certainly doesn't seem to be enough time does there? Hope that all is well with you, and still feel free to reach out should you ever have any questions. I'm still a go player no matter what!
item.content:encoded: Thanks Molokai. I certainly miss writing here and getting to see everyone’s input on things. There certainly doesn’t seem to be enough time does there? Hope that all is well with you, and still feel free to reach out should you ever have any questions. I’m still a go player no matter what!

item.title: Comment on Off In Development World… by MolokaiCowboy
item.dc:creator: MolokaiCowboy
item.description: I hope the coding goes well, Master Ben. I miss your blog but do understand that life calls..."There never seems to be enough time to do the things you want to do once you find them."
item.content:encoded: I hope the coding goes well, Master Ben. I miss your blog but do understand that life calls…”There never seems to be enough time to do the things you want to do once you find them.”

item.title: Comment on Encountering My First Chess Advocate by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: Amen to that! Go is a strategy game for all to play. Down with 'Eastern mysticism'!
item.content:encoded: Amen to that! Go is a strategy game for all to play. Down with ‘Eastern mysticism’!

item.title: Comment on Encountering My First Chess Advocate by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: I think at the time my co-worker was speaking more in terms of the complexities of individual pieces. After thinking about it for some time, I realized that people who haven't played go don't realize that the complexity with go does not lie in single pieces; but the overarching connections and dynamic value that changes as the game progresses.
item.content:encoded: I think at the time my co-worker was speaking more in terms of the complexities of individual pieces. After thinking about it for some time, I realized that people who haven’t played go don’t realize that the complexity with go does not lie in single pieces; but the overarching connections and dynamic value that changes as the game progresses.

item.title: Comment on Off In Development World… by Ben Hong
item.dc:creator: Ben Hong
item.description: Thanks! I definitely miss the game, but there just isn't enough time in the day anymore. Hopefully one day I can get back to blogging about go once again.
item.content:encoded: Thanks! I definitely miss the game, but there just isn’t enough time in the day anymore. Hopefully one day I can get back to blogging about go once again.

item.title: Comment on Encountering My First Chess Advocate by grok
item.dc:creator: grok
item.description: One thing I hope for is that Go loses the 'Eastern mysticism' and 'traditionalist' ,angle. It can well stand on its own, post-feudal era.
item.content:encoded: One thing I hope for is that Go loses the ‘Eastern mysticism’ and ‘traditionalist’ ,angle. It can well stand on its own, post-feudal era.
